head.title: T-Bird Watchers Can Snare a Rare Old Species

hedline.hl1: T-Bird Watchers Can Snare a Rare Old Species

block.p: THE official announcement took no one by surprise: Ford said last week that it would bring back the Thunderbird, this time as a two-seat roadster closely modeled on a concept car that was a sensation at auto shows last year.

THE official announcement took no one by surprise: Ford said last week that it would bring back the Thunderbird, this time as a two-seat roadster closely modeled on a concept car that was a sensation at auto shows last year.

The 2002 T-Bird, which goes into production early next year, will pick up where the 1955-57 left off. For '58, the T-Bird became a larger, heavier four-seat car, and in later years it grew bloated and overwrought. But Ford says the next-generation T-Bird is a modern interpretation of the original, complete with turquoise emblems and porthole windows in the removable hardtop.

To stir up interest in the new car, even though dealers have not begun to take orders, Ford is kicking off a summerlong T-bird-watching contest that will culminate in a giveaway of three original models.

Starting this weekend in metropolitan New York, Southern California and South Florida, three white mid-50's roadsters will drive through 144 communities. People who spot one of the cars -- they wear decals identifying them as part of Ford's American Dream Car Tour -- can register to win one. Entries can be made over the Internet at www.fordvehicles.com or by mail at Dream Car, Box 1955, Young America, Minn. 55594; entrants should provide the day, city and approximate location where they saw one of the special cars. Winners are to be announced in October.

Price guides put the value of 1955-57 models -- the favorites of collectors -- at $16,000 to $50,000. The '02 model, which will use the rear-drive chassis and V-8 engine of the Lincoln LS sedan, is expected to start around $35,000.
